g.text: INFRASTRUCTURE
FUNCTIONALITY GROUP
FUNCTIONALITY
DATA SOURCE
RETURNS DATA
SAVING TO DATA
SOURCE
DB
As an argument to speciﬁc functionality provide
instance of Request Object ( do not reuse
Application Service Request Object )
Infrastructure returns mapped data to Domain Model
from any type of source ( our even combined sources )
Given functionality depending on
implementation contains it's own models.
It can be entities, or any other objects
related to speciﬁc data source structure
Infrastructure have access only to Core Layer, do no have access to UI
layer and it's dependencies
Infrastructure layer deﬁnes mappers for domain models for any type of the
data source. Example: UserRepository returns User Domain Model which is
translated data from User Entity ( assuming that data source is DB
For speciﬁc data source, you use data from
Request Object and translate to speciﬁc data
input format ( data for queries, entities, ﬁles,
external services etc.)
EXTERNAL STORAGE / SERVICE
DOMAIN MODEL
DOMAIN MODEL
DOMAIN MODEL
DOMAIN MODEL
DOMAIN SERVICE
DOMAIN SERVICE
APPLICATION SERVICE
CORE
Core Layer ( speciﬁc service method ) returns result
of business logic in form of Domain Model
Domain model is a business model related
to
speciﬁc domain. Do not add here any ui
related ﬁelds. If you need to do it then
deﬁne UI Model and translate domain
model to UI Model with use of Mapper
Domain Service is an abstraction over functionality of
infrastructure and has it's request objects. For example you
have a User service and you want to fetch user from some
data source ( but from domain perspective it doesn't matter
from what data source ). You deﬁne simply UserRepository
interface with it's own Request Object and it doesn't matter
what datasource will implement it ( Database, File, etc )
Core Layer do not have access to UI and Infrastructure. It's
fully independent layer contains only business logic
Application service contains multiple
domain services which are injected by DI.
It has business logic in context of speciﬁc
domain. For every method you deﬁne
Request Object as a clear deﬁnition of
input
CORE ASKS
INFRASTRUCTURE
( THROUGH FACADE )
CORE RETURNS
BUSINESS LOGIC
RESULT
INTERNAL \ EXTERNAL USER
USER INTERFACE
BOUNDED CONTEXT
DOMAIN
CLIENT REQUESTS
SERVER RESPONDS
WEB
UI Layer have access only to Core Layer, do not have access to
Infrastructure and it's dependencies
As an argument to application service
method you provide instance of Request Object
UI Layer, depending on protocol returns data in
speciﬁc format, if there are differences in
structure between returned data by service and
structure required by protocol use UI Mapper
and translate Domain Data to UI Model Data
Domain contains deﬁnition of entry
points for speciﬁc protocols ( like
GraphQL or Rest etc.) . It may contain
it's own models, helpers, utils etc.
UI Layer deﬁnes it's own UI layer models, but from my perspective there can
be exception. If response body format is exactly the same as business model I
think that it's allowed to just return Domain model. Domain model is not
polluted ( like in case of persistence ) by additional ﬁelds. Here you have to be
careful though - if there is a need to have additional ﬁeld on UI then deﬁne UI
model and do not use Domain Model. The key here is to not move any UI
related logic into Core Layer
UI ASKS CORE
INFRASTRUCTURE
RETURNS TRANSLATED
DATA
DEPENDENCY INJECTION
DEPENDENCY INJECTION
